Bakaia^ce,.- - h.2.Sw Dear Sir, In connection with its operations, the Company is considering alternative methods of softening water. One of the processes under consideration requires fairly large quan tities of salt. During the past few years the Company has obtained quantities of salt (about two or three tons a day) from salt basins located a few miles south of the town of Zellaq, the salt being mined by local inhabitants acting in the capacity of contractors and using the crudest methods involving scraping up the salt from the surface of the naturally existing evaporation ponds. To obtain the necessary quantities of salt for the proposed new scheme it will be necessary to expend a considerable amount of money on installations at the salt ponds area involving drainage canals, concrete lined evaporation ponds, pumps, roads, etc. It is the opinion of our geologists that there is an ample supply of salt obtainable in the area above-mentioned enough to last for many 1 years at the increased rate of consumption. Before proceeding further with our consideration of this problem we desire to know whether or not the area involved is Government land or privately owned and whether there are any existing rights to this salt deposit heM by others. I discussed this question briefly with Mr. Belgrave over the telephone yesterday morning. Yours very ty\s\ W. P. physicalDescription.extent: The documents in the file are arranged in chronological order. There is an index at the end of the file (folio 6). The index is arranged chronologically and refers to documents within the file; it gives brief description of the correspondence with a reference number which refers back to that correspondence in the file.
The foliation is written in pencil, in the top right corner. It begins on the cover, on number 1, and runs through to 7, on the inside of the back cover of the file.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Bahrain Petroleum Company Limited, the Political Agent at Bahrain and the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain on the rights for extracting salt from Zellaq, Bahrain, for the purpose of softening water.There is an index at the end of the volume (folio 6).
